commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Amazon wrapper  (3)
2. Prepared statement?  (2)(5)
3. Drive around the office  (4)(5)
4. Volume of tourists  (6)(5)
5. Musical production that might include grunts, groans, thwops, snorts and barks  (9)


BOA
I'M READY
WORK ETHIC
TRAVEL GUIDE
WHALESONG

If there could be a better example of an unobjectionable, by the numbers Monday puzzle this would be it. Not much to comment on. I will say I just discovered that I have been using PERUSE wrong all my life‚ÄîI always assumed it meant to read something leisurely and sporadically‚Äîbut as I looked it up I discovered I was wrong. My only other comment is I think SEXTing involves more than ‚Äújust‚Äù sending an eggplant emoji, although I get it
Cool theme, is spite of frozen polar chill of December.

Santa Claus and a penguin are also polar opposites.

("Oh, yeah, icy that.")

Speaking of frozen things. We are renting a smart home‚Äîwhich wasn‚Äôt my first choice but here we are‚Äîand so we‚Äôre plagued by (to me) random advice and admonishments from a disembodied voice which doesn‚Äôt always respond to my, ‚ÄúNot now, Google; shut up!‚Äù  This morning, as I was brewing the coffee, Google announced that the freezing fog we were experiencing would be, ‚Äúdeposited, leading to rime on roads. Use caution.‚Äù  Huh, I thought and said, ‚ÄúHey Google, did you just wax poetic and say, ‚Äòrime?‚Äô‚Äù Google waited a beat, then said brightly, ‚ÄúThe laundry is finished. Please unload the laundry.‚Äù

That was the end of our witty banter, but all day I kept bugging my husband to go for a drive on the ‚Äúroads covered in rime. Rime!‚Äù My husband has a wordless look for times like these. ‚ÄúBut honey,‚Äù I said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs rime! We now live in a place where rime has left the literary realm and become a reality I can drive over!‚Äù (I have used a lot of exclamation points today.) My husband gave me another look and said that Google had announced rime many times over the past year but I never paid any attention. Also, that there was rime covering spider webs on the lawn furniture and the one hanging right outside the kitchen window in front of which I‚Äôd ground the beans just minutes earlier.

Well, he can‚Äôt spoil my joy. 40-odd years in this planet‚Äôs high desert regions had never brought rime to my daily vocabulary. Today I get to report from beneath otherwise miserable frozen fog that I‚Äôve got RIME!
If my streak ends at 135, so be it. We leave at dawn for Fredberg mountain. Allegedly we'll have wifi back at the base camp Tuesday night, but it's unreliable. So we'll see...

How ever would I learn if I didn‚Äôt do the puzzle? I didn‚Äôt expect to learn a new countryon a Monday, let alone feel saved from a future mis-usage. As SP already noted below, using PERUSE to mean a casual reading is so widely accepted that it‚Äôs a ‚Äúthing,‚Äù apparently.  Today‚Äôs clue is accurate. 

When I‚Äôm perusing a painting at the museum, it‚Äôs a lingering look. But with documents, I‚Äôve connected the word more with a once-over; something closer to ‚Äúscan.‚Äù Though, come to think of it, a computer scan is a perfect copy, no? 

ALSO, I learn all sorts of things while trying to make my incorrect guesses fit (FROZENAssets, I‚Äôm talkin‚Äô to you). 

When I see a banality such as ECHO right off the bat, I can get a little humfy. Ms. Binney rewarded my continuing with abundant GRACENOTEs and RIFFs of fun.  any trip that includes PARIS is not wasted. Nice Monday.

@emus: üçÜ?

(That's an eggplant emoji). The emus and their cousins the rheas think I'm making them moussaka for dinner. Won't they be surprised!

Lively puzzle, the NE corner pleasingly Tuesday-Wednesday in pushback, slowed me down to a time equal to that which "DC" yesterday claimed to have solved Sunday's. Haha, DC, Dutch-Iris got you good! [See yesterday's comments, top recommended]

The sub theme, which naturally takes place on ice, is the Edmonton Oiler who went down on his KNEE PADS after taking an opponent's OAR right in his LAP and lay PRONE, staring up to PERUSE the DIM faces of PACKS of his teammates, who shouted words of encouragement at him: "Way to go, ACE!" "I'm gonna RIP his ITSY aubergine off and GNAW on it!" Then he SLEPT, waking from a dream while he was being life flighted to OHARE, a dream in which CAGES of ASLAN-like lions were opened as if in the middle of a MAGIC ACT and the lions all came out in a HOP and a LEAP, and then George Takei was there, standing there with TRACES in his hands, as if he was the master and each of the lions his SERF, and Takei would call out to one, "COOL, CAT!" and to another "Take a CHILL PILL!" until he had them all organized -- and then all the lions and Takei started to dance a wild POLKA...and then the dream faded from his memory, leaving only its DIM ECHO.

Timely theme! Here‚Äôs my ‚Äúfavorite‚Äù (/s) cold front coinage:

WINTRY MIX.

Any day now - I may have to remind myself to be a COOL CAT and take a CHILL PILL.

TIL that the largest joint in the body is not the hip.

(Or I missed a pun of some sort)

This puzzle was so easy, I hit a new Monday PB.

I didn't even notice the theme until after I was done.

COOLBEANS.
Yay we got RIFF instead of VAMP today. And some delightful trivia.

Fun puzzle which I solved in my average Monday time. Not sure if a reminder of wintry weather ahead in NYC as December approaches is welcome. Can‚Äôt wait for spring to begin here in earnest in May.

I do have a nit to pick. To my understanding, a precursor is replaced by the new iteration. If so, then the mainframe is not a precursor to the supercomputer. In fact, Control Data Corporation and Cray Research made mainframe computers which were called supercomputers. 

From wiki: ‚ÄúMainframes and supercomputers cannot always be clearly distinguished; up until the early 1990s, many supercomputers were based on a mainframe architecture with supercomputing extensions.‚Äù

This was a good one! Took a bit longer than my usual. Some I didn't know that were obvious, some difficult ones that I surprisingly knew (anyone who has watched Madame Secretary a few times knows what the small country is)! The one that puzzled me was the hospital gloves. LATEX is very rarely used due to prevalence of allergies. Still a fun one! And learned the largest joint in the body is indeed NOT the hip as I thought it was! 

Stay cool y'all

You know you have some unresolved previous work trauma when 1A "Office announcement" makes you think: layoffs, job has been eliminated, we just reduced 10% of our human assets, etc. 

Would have had to be some pretty big rebus squares, but it really was what first came to mind. Alas, 'tis life.  I am the far, far better for it, as it turned out, but it sure has left some ugly scars. 

Fun puzzle! Only small setbacks were dock before PIER and corn before MASA...  and I've not heard GRACENOTE before. Being a big fan of grace, in general, I'm now a fan of the phrase‚Äîeven though I'm not musically inclined. I'm thankful for the numerous non-musical grace notes that have appeared throughout my life! 

Cheers to the week ahead!
Fun n cute!

Well, shiver me timbers, this theme is timely.

It'd be warmer in Nauru, but the wiki article on Nauru doesn't make it seem inviting in any other way. YMMV.

Fun puzzle, and I liked the theme, bit I have 2 nits:

MACH 1 is incorrect usage. Ernst Mach determined the speed of sound in air. In his honor it was called the MACH NUMBER. Initially I was thought to be an absolute limit, like Einstein‚Äôs speed of light. When this was demonstrated to be wrong a number was added as a means of measuring. But the speed of sound in air is still referred to as the Mach Number. 

The other is that oil tankers do not carry drums, they carry their cargo in enormous tanks. 

L

Came here to whine over ‚Äúperuse‚Äù meaning ‚Äúread thoroughly‚Äù ‚Äî I‚Äôve spent my whole life perusing things at a brisk skim. Turns out I‚Äôve been using it wrong for decades. The word literally means careful, detailed reading. Guess I‚Äôve been ‚Äúbrowsing‚Äù this whole time. Suppose that‚Äôs why it‚Äôs called a ‚Äúweb browser‚Äù instead of a ‚Äúweb peruser.‚Äù  You win this round NYT.
Oh My, that George TAKEI is one COOL CAT. And these guys here are COOL for CATs. https://youtu.be/iTVHOarV338?si=zUCB58gRWlsGkt5o

someone recently suggested here that i make early-week puzzles more challenging for myself by solving them using only across or down clues.
which i did today.
but an unanticipated problem with this is that i only understand half the comments.
Today I learned that PERUSE is a contronym and my life will never be the same.

This was quite enjoyable. However, I found the SE sector quite hard to complete - GRACE NOTES and MASA were unknown to me, and I've never seen that particular usage of DEWY. I had to rely on crosses for TRACES, too.

It's interesting how my native tongue influences my understanding of English. The FUNGI thing was a really good - as in, bad - pun. I got it late though, because I have a tendency to pronounce Latin words as I was taught in Polish. For us the word sounds differently: foon-ghee. Of course I know how Americans say it, but it's not the first thing that comes to mind.

Our headstones don't say RIP. The most common abbreviation for Polish Catholics is ≈öP, short for "≈õwiƒôtej pamiƒôci", literally "one who is remembered as holy/blessed". The thing is, as a graphical flourish, a cross is usually inserted between the two letters, and in effect the whole thing looks like "≈õtp", or at least I thought so as a kid, and for years I wondered what ≈õ t p could be short for ü§£. Why I never asked my parents about it, I'll never know. I must have been in my teens by the time I realized my mistake ü§™
Best wishes for a good Birthday. I, too, am a December baby.
Boats can be tied up at a PIER, moor, dock, or, more broadly, a port. All unhelpfully 4-lettered locations. Must remember to fill those in last in future.
Happy Birthday! Sagittarius or Capricorn?

59A
"You should come foraging with me, because I'm a ___" (bad pun)

Foraging for what? Never said "No" to a threesome......or foursome. or fivesome

I've known some FUNGis in my life....but there the ONE I like best...Well, he's among us.

Not too shabby today. 
One look-up, which was frustrating. I could only think of Steve for Curry, which didn't fit, and STEPH just didn't occur to me. Slightly harder I thought, for Monday.
Because my furnace has not been working properly since Thanksgiving even though repairment have been here twice, and it it now 60 in my house, this was the perfect Monday puzzle!!!
A welcome challenge for a Monday. I love it! More like this to start the week.

All these wonderful icy puns were reminiscent of Arnold Schwarzenegger‚Äôs incredibly poorly RATED turn as Mr Freeze in Batman Forever, which is one of my favourite bad movies of all time. Perhaps I‚Äôll PERUSE my movie collection and make time to rewatch it for some nostalgia, though Tim Burton‚Äôs Bat makes for a much more festive bit of popcorn‚Ä¶ my taste in movies has MATURED but I do still love to DIGIN to my old favourites (But now I‚Äôm dreaming of a world with Shatner as Batman and George TAKEI as Robin‚Ä¶ oh my!).

Fun puzzle today, shaved a little off my PB but I did have to look up MASA, which was totally new to me, and GRACENOTE was only solved by the crosses. Tripped myself up by seeing LL Cool J and defaulting to RNB before RAP, and the Eggplant had me thinking someone was being HORNY in their SEXTS, but otherwise this was a lovely solve to start the week‚Ä¶ Now if anyone wants to fly me out to PARIS to see the COLDFRONT come in and cover the city in a lovey layer of DEWY snow, I‚Äôm ready to HOP onto the next flight!
One of those rare days that I got all the themed clues right without any help. Nice puzzle to start off the week.
Anybody else call their anti-anxiety medication a chill pill?

I liked seeing PERUSE, a word with two contrary meanings ‚Äì a contronym ‚Äì sharing the box with POLAR OPPOSITE.

PERUSE is not alone in our magnificent quirky language.  Other words of the same ilk are ‚Äúgarnish‚Äù (add or withhold), ‚Äúsanction‚Äù (approval or penalty), and ‚Äúseed‚Äù (remove or add seeds).

There was more to like in the box as well.  A watery subtheme, with PIER, OAR, DEWY, a backward TIDE, and wannabe SERF.  CAT crossing ACT.  Long-O enders to counter the icy starters ‚Äì ECHO, MEMO, ALSO, ECO, ZERO.  And PADS, combined with (COOL) CAT, reminded me of TOE BEANS, a lovely answer from Hanna‚Äôs last puzzle.

FUNGI.  My latest food-love discovery ‚Äì mushroom jerky.  It‚Äôs a thing.  I found it at our farmer‚Äôs market, and it‚Äôs yummy and satisfying to the core, at least to me.  Do you like savory, spicy, and GNAW-able?  Mushroom jerky.

Thank you, Hannah, for all these day-lifting pings!

Fungi foraging puns?
I prefer something a little cheesier.
(Maybe some nippy cheddar, today?)

But what a bright, crisp Monday puzzle!

Nice Monday puzzle and a cute theme. A lot of things not coming to me just from the clues, but everything fell together with working the crosses. And... was almost done when I finally caught on to the theme. That's always a nice touch. Puzzle find today - A Thursday from March 18, 1999 by Rand H. Burns. Some theme answers. SWAGMAN TUCKERBAG BILLABONG JUMBUCK All of those clued in part as a reference to "today's theme," which was... WALTZINGMATILDA (an old favorite). Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/18/1999&g=37&d=A ...
EGGPLANT? Really ?? Oh, my! No wonder I get the side-eye in the produce department. üò≥

Important reminder, please peruse quickly and painstakingly:

On Sam Corbin Day Eve I'll be hosting my annual Sam Corbin Tree Trimming Jamboree.

As usual it's a potluck. Sam of course will be bringing her famous sticky puns. Let me know what you'll be bringing. We need cheese(Gouda not bada) and bonbon mots and potato quips and anything else you feel like making!



(No Oreos, please.)
Apt puzzle, as when I got up early to move my car this morning, it was only 8 degrees out. It was so cold my peach emoji almost froze off.

And... my late puzzle find. A Thursday from August 11, 2011 by Parker Lewis. I've never seen another one like this. Theme clues and answers: "3, 6, 11, 18, 27 ..." XSQUAREDPLUSTWO "4, 2, 4/3, 1, 4/5 ..." TWENTYOVERFIVEX "8, 1, -18, -55, -116 ..." NINEMINUSXCUBED And the 'reveals': "Any of the clues for 17-, 34- or 57-Across" SEQUENCE "In the answers to 17-, 34- and 57-Across, it was replaced in turn by 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 ..." VARIABLE One time math major here, but I can't imagine having any chance at figuring that one out. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/11/2011&g=17&d=A ...

On a Monday, my crosswords' hope is that I be mildly amused by the theme, and this one more than satisfied my expectations.

The cherry on top for me is that the revealer is also an example of the theme.  

And I hope that I'm not the only one who thought "Preceder of skip and jump" was going to be "____ skip and _____ jump".  A little Monday misdirect.

Well done!

Under two blankets in front of my freshly cut and trimmed tree, I appreciated this theme! Although I made myself blush assuming 69A might be FLIRT‚Äî before realizing you‚Äôve likely advanced past the flirting stage if eggplant emojis are involved. Out of practice!
Cute puzzle. Found NE corner impenetrable. Stay warm today!

I know I have a reputation of being an annoying ‚Äúfact man‚Äù, but there are some misconceptions I simply cannot abide.

A cold front is the leading edge of a cold(er) air mass, not the air mass itself which causes the chilling. It is the dividing line between colder and warmer air, and is the frequent location of precipitation. Cold fronts exist in summer, as well. So they don‚Äôt chill anybody then.

It's Monday! We have a Midi! It's a new month! We have a Bonus Puzzle! I'm using too many!!!!

I'm out of breath!

I loved this puzzle...cute clues, fun fill, and fast, as in: Monday. Still, I had to break it up to do some Monday routine things (backup my laptop, water my orchid, stuff like that). I think I'll leave the bonus puzzle for when I'm at my volunteer desk. It remains to be seen whether or not that will hex the ER into having a crazy day, or if it will be one of those when I get to sit and do not much of anything for a while. Here's hoping people did their driving safely, and yesterday, and have finished their leftovers, or stored them properly, so we don't have a lot of stomach issues today. 

Happy solving, peeps!

Oh - one more puzzle find. Absolutely the most unusual one I've ever encountered. A Sunday from August 13, 2014 by Joel Fagliano (!) with the title: "Heard at the movies." The 'reveal': "What you get when you say 23-, 31-, 47-, 64-, 79- or 97-Across out loud" BESTPICTUREWINNER And some of those referenced clues and answers: "Jewish bread/Played, as a violin/Throw (1950)" CHALLAHBOWEDHEAVE "Toyota rival/Measure of power/Insult (1954)" HONDAWATTAFFRONT "Reside/Savage/Puzzle (out)/Wash (2013)" DWELLFIERCESUSSLAVE "Hooligan/Strange/Silo contents (1972)" THUGODDFODDER "Wildlife protector/Difficult/Hotel door feature (1980)" WARDENHAIRYPEEPHOLE "In what way?"/Like overcooked steak/Possess/European capital on a gulf (1985) HOWTOUGHHAVERIGA Can't imagine having any kind of chance at solving that one. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/31/2014&g=31&d=A ...

I have little to say other than "Over too soon!  Please, Miss, may I have some more?"

I forgot about the bonus puzzle, so off I go to print it for dessert.

What a delightful Monday puzzle -- thank you for such clever clues, Hannah! With the northeast preparing for its first big(ish) snowstorm of the season, the timing of today's puzzle was perfect. As I write this, my little city is under a winter storm "watch" but we know that it won't be that big of a deal unless it's upgraded to a winter storm "warning." Of course, the biggest question always comes from our excited children here in Maine who, on cue, are already anxiously asking, "Are we gonna have a snow day tomorrow?" Time will tell . . .‚ùÑÔ∏è

Happy December, everyone -- stay warm!
Okay, but you know they don‚Äôt put oil in barrels before putting it on a ship, right?
Nice way to start up the cranial engine this first chilly week of December. Thanks Hannah!

Note to Sam (sam.corbin@nytimes.com): I believe the term hop skip and jump was the common name for the Olympic event we now call the Triple Jump. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_jump You Learn Something Every Day Department: I now know that a rhea is a kangaroo-like animal. I previously only knew of Rhea Perlman, who is probably grateful that her parents named her as they did (although Kangaroo Perlman would be a great show business name). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhea_Perlman Kismet Department: first thing this morning I put a huge, meaty ham bone into a slow cooker with pre-soaked split peas, then found pea soup to be a clue/answer in both Connections and the Crossword. I must be doing something right. https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/1019881-split-pea-soup?unlocked_article_code=1.5U8.vXh7.6hcs_gypWYRu&smid=share-url

Perfectly Monday ‚ò∫Ô∏è and I solved it faster than my usual, but no thanks to the NE corner.

 I didn‚Äôt know 10D, 11D, or 12D, and sat puzzling over 19A for minutes. G _ _ _ E‚Ä¶ could be  ?? GloveE, as in the box? No, that can‚Äôt be it. GratE? No. GearE? That‚Äôs not even a word. Could this person‚Äôs name be EVA or EVe? EVy? 

So I went for EVA, guessed it must be a vowel in that third position in NAURU, filled in GAUGE and finally understood ‚ÄúDIG IN‚Äù as the sought-for synonym to ‚ÄúDinner is served!‚Äù

And TIL that a rhea is a flightless South American bird, but also Rhea is the name of a goddess in Greek mythology (apparently a ‚ÄúTitanis‚Äù or mother of the gods).

Thanks, Hannah Binney, for this delightful Monday puzzle. TIL there is a country called NAURU. The theme was clever and, whereas some Monday puzzles are over too soon, this one had me going back to correct a few things here and there. 
I will have to find out at some point what these Bonus puzzles are that some of you referred to. 
Stay warm everyone üéÑ‚ùÑÔ∏èüéø

This puzzle was an absolute delight!  Fun clues, great theme to match the weather, and I learned a few things like the small country and a music flair.

It can't be easy to create a Monday-worthy puzzle that is still so much fun to solve.  Warm winter hat off to you!

Fun Monday! 

One nit regarding largest joint in the body: The hip is quite a bit larger than the KNEE, is it not?
First ever crossword completed without hints or checks!

Henry, and Klaus, riff on today's theme: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8wBWBfkuyvE&list=RD8wBWBfkuyvE&start_radio=1 Kate, and Stephen, offer a few grid-spanners (some of may not be accepted by the Bee): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1v9SDaljUO4&list=RD1v9SDaljUO4&start_radio=1

Latex has not been used for hospital gloves and so much of what we use is latex free that now we mark anything that has latex instead of the other way around. 

Just FYI.
I do love to hate a contranym (aka Janus word).

The triple jump (see 32D) is a prime example of why the Summer Games are silly. You can get a proper gold medal for five or ten minutes of work, while a soccer player has to play six or seven 90-minute games for the same honor. Hopefully, the other Olympians tease them. "Oh look, it's Skippy!"

Just wanted to point out that the attack from the right about the examples chosen for the answer FLOTUS (in yesterday's puzzle) is still there, except that most of the replies have been removed.

So the NYT removed many highly recommended replies, but did not remove his initial attack that the NYT only allows "liberal" things.

There is some fine irony here.

53 DOWN:  "Hospital glove material"

The clue is incorrect.  Many patients, especially those born with meningomyelocele ("Spina Bifida") are allergic to latex. 

Latex on intact skin is generally OK, but exposure of internal tissue membranes can generate severe reactions.  

To avoid the myriad problems in stocking 2 different types of gloves, hospitals order latex-free gloves exclusively.

fun puzzle but way too many 'downer' clues the entire puzzle should have been weather related or variations on 'cool' words
that kinda thing - good effort nonetheless!
Eggplant, sext clue, really? Eww... maybe I'm just getting old.

Great crossword today ‚ò∫Ô∏è only thing to point out is that ‚Äúmasa‚Äù isn‚Äôt an ingredient. It‚Äôs the dough (or ‚Äúmix‚Äù if you want something in English that sounds similar). Would be a bit like saying batter is an ingredient of pancakes üòÖ

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Plant eater]  (5)(7)
[Take it back!]  (4)(7)


VENUS FLYTRAP
TIME MACHINE

Hi, @Lewis!
I have been very slowly working backwards through the archives. On my lunch break at work today, as it happened, began the Thurs. Apr. 19th puzzle, and *just* finished it over dinner. Looked up, and noticed it was by you! Very fun, tricksy Thurs.--the revealer was BACK TO SQUARE ONE. (How well do you remember your own puzzles, I wonder?) Anyway, I enjoyed it very much: Thank You!

Happy Thanksgiving to you and yours--
BiD
@Bill -- Oh, I'm very glad you liked it, and thank you for those kind words.  I do remember that puzzle; it's one of my favorites of those I've made.  And I hope your Thanksgiving was grand!
@Lewis Whales *bark?*
Moira, Yes. Whales bark. https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/baby-humpback-whales-burp-and-bark-to-beg-mom-for-milk/

@SP

Oh one more comment‚Äînot a nit, per se, just an observation‚Äîmost hospitals do not use LATEX gloves routinely anymore because of the high prevalence of LATEX allergies‚Äîjust so you know.

@SBK

Right!? It's bananas!! If ever I attain any sort of power, it'll be the very first thing I fix. Har! Okay, maybe there are a few other priorities, but still‚Äîtop five!

Mike,
I can't cap that one.

@Mike

That's why Santa never says to a penguin, "You, sleigh me!"  He knows it's a wrong latitude.
@Mike That‚Äôs why you‚Äôll never catch Santa signing his Christmas cards with an autopenguin

Mike,

Please, when using ‚Äúpolar‚Äù in your puns,
try to use the definite arcticles.

@Sam Lyons

I think there‚Äôs a poem in there somewhere‚ÄîRime of the AI Moderator?

@SP

Or "Rime of the AIncient Monitor."

@Sam Lyons: (done laughing out loud now.)
Would you be more concerned if google said there was hoar deposited on the roads?

@Sam Lyons

No rime or reason to Google.

@Sam Lyons

I can't think of a greater domestic horror than living in a Big Capitalist Brother house that keeps listening in on everything that's going on, even poetry would be involved. Jesus...
@SP This is brilliant! And it turns out I‚Äôve been misreading ‚ÄúAIbatross‚Äù all this time!

@Sam Lyons

The first thing I do when I get any new device is turn off personalization, digital assistants, routines, location history, etc. I couldn't live in a "smart" home. The idea is beyond abhorrent and I shudder thinking about it. Maybe it's about being born under a dictatorship? Our privacy was hard won, and giving it up - to the state or a corporate behemoth - is simply unthinkable.

@Andrzej

I‚Äôm with you on this. If I were Sam or her husband, I would intentionally feed Google false information about myself all day long.
@Sam Lyons I love your joy for rime! We had a stunning hoar frost last week, and I was ranting (and sure, spelling) for days...

@Andrzej
Per contra, my new apt/flat has very efficient toilets with a ferocious flush that looks as though it's about to leap out of the bowl every time. I now must put the lid down before I flush -- every time. (Advisable in any case due to aerosols caused by flushing!)

@Sam Lyons

What's wrong with a bidet? Not seeing any in the US was very weird.

@Andrzej

I may not be able to fully convey how‚Ä¶ wrong the sight of a bidet is to the Yankee soul. In fact, I suspect it‚Äôs the bidet and not, as is commonly held, the death of peat moss economy that made my forbears become Yankees in the first place. They were fleeing a place where bathrooms had more water taps than a person requires. It went against their minimalist Nordic aesthetic sense.

@Sam Lyons

ü§∑üèΩ

@Sam Lyons

Bidets are always in the Costco catalog and locals who buy them wax poetic about what a wonderful addition they are to their American bathrooms. 

On the other hand, our upstairs bathroom has a high tank toilet with a pull chain, an Enarc (Crane spelled backwards); it is the best toilet ever. It's more than 100 years old (was in our 2007 house when we bought it), the oak tank stripped down to the beautiful wood that was under multiple coats of paint, and relined with copper, the super-high-quality porcelain bowl still glisteningly, perfectly white, and the seat replaced. 

Why the high tank toilet style was abandoned I will never understand.  Gravity means it uses less water, and it never fails to do what it was meant to do.

You can find lesser restored antiques online  for +$1K. The downstairs toilet is a low-flush style that has been a pain in the neck from the git-go.

I must say, I would opt for the woods, but I would never trust that I'd found all the AI recording equipment and turned it off. You may not be alone in your bathroom.

@dutchiris
Why the high tank was abandoned: lower ceilings. So, less falling distance,  less accumulated force, less successful flushing. And unsuccessful flushing is the death of any plumbing fixture. As soon as the apartment block with its 8-foot ceilings (reduced to 7 ft with internal clearance space) became common, the high tank was doomed.

@SBK

Our house is tiny, but ceilings are 9.5 ft.  Mystrery solved.  Thanks!

@dutchiris

@jennie Though fine as a clue in and of itself, "formerly" thrown in would def help ease the frets of those who have to suffer it. It's always a sad story when something like an allergy becomes a phobia of healthcare such that their health is harmed again as a secondary effect.

AySz88,
Are you speaking from personal experience? If not, I'm not sure "formerly" in the clue would make a (former?) sufferer feel any better. I don't feel any better about having had it when ETHER is clued as an [Old-time anesthetic], as it was three weeks ago.

@Barry Ancona

I think the complaint is valid, but has nothing to do with personal reactions to the substance.

Latex is seldom used in hospitals unless there is no alternative, due to the allergies, and the word is not often heard in healthcare (and hasn't been for some time) except to ask about allergies.

Nitrile gloves are the current standard, with vinyl gloves occasionally seen for some non-critical tasks. The continued use of "latex gloves" in conversation, crosswords or elsewhere implies that they're still being used, which is not the case, and could cause some people to hesitate in seeking care.

It's more a case of presenting as current use a practice which has gone by the wayside due to safety and health concerns. "Former" or "formerly-used" would have been more appropriate.

@HJ & FiGM-- In standard "classical" music theory, "grace notes" are notes which are not absolutely essential--the melody and harmony would work just fine without them--but ornament and add, um, "gracefulness" to the music, and most often it's hard to imagine them not there. They're usually--but not always--of short duration, and typically printed smaller then the rest of the notes. Here's a YouTube of a "scrolling score" of the opening of J.S. Bach's "Goldberg Variations"--and you can see the "little notes" go by. (Those little squiggly lines and curlicues over some of the notes are notational shorthand for various kinds of melodic ornamentation as well. Baroque music was full of that): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=574PayNClHE&list=RD574PayNClHE&start_radio=1 A little more up beat, Francis, but your example by Herb Alpert works well, as well--I assume you mean those little slides in the trumpet line, and the little "diddle-its"* in the brass. *Musicologist will try to tell you the technical term is "mordent," but don't believe them: the techincal term is "diddle-it."

@Bill

Oh, that's neat, Bill! I like seeing the squiggly lines and hearing the ornamentations. It's been a very long time since I read music (I played the clarinet in Jr. High and a couple years of HS, but didn't keep at it) but this makes sense to me. ‚ò∫Ô∏è Thank you!

@LarryF Did the clue mention oil tankers? OIL DRUMs are by definition containers that carry oil. They may be on a cargo ship from the Middle East, a train from Tulsa or a truck from Texas. As long as it's possible, the clue is fine. As for MACH 1, NASA uses the term, and that's good enough for me. Or a crossword editor: https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/airplane/mach.html

@LarryF

To add to Steve's comment, there are oils that are used for other purposes, and on an ocean-going ship, it's likely that lubricating oil might be found in drums on board due to quantities needed. There are other types of oil that could end up being shipped in drums for later processing or bottling.

@LarryF I'll agree on OILDRUM. Yeah, you could have an oil drum on a ship from the Middle East, like an egg carton or any other container, but that's not how you move oil. If you had an oil drum on this ship, it would have something in it for running the ship, it wouldn't be for the cargo. It's just off base for a Monday-level clue. 

The thought of transporting oil from the Middle East in drums did make me laugh out loud, though, so that's a plus. And it would make spills a whole lot easier to clean up.

American mycologists almost uniformly say fun-gi with a long i. I usually assume that someone who says fun-guy is not an expert, unless they are making a very old joke.

@Barbara
I don‚Äôt understand‚Ä¶a long i rhymes with guy. Do you mean a long e?

@Andrzej
In NoAm, as in most of the English-speaking world, we follow the British version of Latin phonics when using Latin loanwords like fungi. But if you study Latin formally, you get what is the new classic pronunciation. Different values for vowels and consonantal J and V. English vee-va voh-chei becomes wee-wa wo-kei. 
I remember a charming legal parody in which a lawyer speaking the revised version walked into court seeking an order of mahn-dah-moos (mandamus) and could not make himself understood.
Pax wo-bis-koom.

I doubt you'd ever see MOOR clued as a place; in crossworld, it's a verb, albeit one often clued by [Dock], which can be a noun or a verb.

PORT has been clued as the harbor in general, or the left side of the ship, or a wine, but never specifically as a synonym to "dock" or "pier."

STEPH Curry is a star basketball player for the Golden State Warriors, who play in the Bay Area of California (just ask dutchiris!).  His full first name is Stephen, but he pronounces it STEFF-en.

My first name is not Stephen; it's Steven.  When I was young, I didn't even realize there was another way to spell it.  My spelling was the more common one at the time. @SBK
I was unsure about the meaning of your comment. Does the word ‚Äûtable‚Äú somehow fall into the contronym category? I was thinking of writing to you that ‚Äûwe recently tabled on freshly foraged mushrooms ‚Äû‚Äî-but then I became unsure and tried googling whether this usage is ok in English. Instead of an answer I got this lovely poem:

Mushrooms (1959)

Overnight, very
Whitely, discreetly,
Very quietly

Our toes, our noses
Take hold on the loam,
Acquire the air.

Nobody sees us,
Stops us, betrays us;
The small grains make room.

Soft fists insist on
Heaving the needles,
The leafy bedding,

Even the paving.
Our hammers, our rams,
Earless and eyeless,

Perfectly voiceless,
Widen the crannies,
Shoulder through holes. We

Diet on water,
On crumbs of shadow,
Bland-mannered, asking

Little or nothing.
So many of us!
So many of us!

We are shelves, we are
Tables, we are meek,
We are edible,

Nudgers and shovers
In spite of ourselves.
Our kind multiplies:

We shall by morning
Inherit the earth.
Our foot's in the door.

   Sylvia Plath

EddyMN,
Where's the beef? 
1) You write that a COLD FRONT is a "frequent location of precipitation." In the winter, that would be snow, [some wintry weather] as per the clue. 
(2) The "front" of COLD FRONT refers to the first words of the themers, not the location of the cold.
(3) That there wouldn't likely be snow with a summer cold front doesn't make the clue incorrect.

@Barry Ancona I know what you are saying, but I was not criticizing the clue. I was merely pointing out that people in general misuse the term ‚Äúcold front‚Äù when they mean ‚Äúcold air mass‚Äù. The front is a dividing line, between air masses, colder and warmer. And the precipitation, even in winter, along the front, is likely rain. Storms, low pressure systems, form along fronts. The warmer and the colder air mix, and you may get snow to the north and west of the low pressure system. But the chill is in the polar outbreak following the front.

EddyMN,
Oh. I see. Posters often offer facts when clues, the column or the comments might lead to an incorrect conclusion. Had you seen anyone here express that misconception you cannot abide?
